text: carnage in Sadr City seems reminiscent
of the dark days of Iraq sectarian war
this vast mainly Shiite district the
scene of so many atrocities witnessing
the worst attack on the capital in
months it was rush hour a pickup truck
explosives hidden under fruit and
vegetables detonating in the midst of a
busy market so-called Islamic state said
it carried out the attack and that it
was aimed at Shiite militiamen that many
of the victims were women some at a
nearby beauty salon preparing for
weddings many people were killed and you
can see blood everywhere they were poor
people who were here to earn their
living they earn just five ten or
fifteen thousand dinars a day and were
killed in cold blood why did this happen
can this corrupt government tell us why
people have been destroyed because of
this government the blast destroyed
vehicles and shops some were smoldering
hours after the attack security has
gradually improved in Baghdad but
large-scale attacks do still take place
is capable of striking fear far beyond
the territory it controls in February a
double suicide bomb killed 70 people
also in Sadr City but other
neighbourhoods were also caught up in
the latest violence with more death and
injury in Adhamiya
and in a mainly Sunni neighborhood in
the West this was the bloodiest day in
Baghdad this year the attacks come in
the midst of a deep political crisis the
government crippled by factional
divisions and parliament unable to meet
while the politicians differ civilians
wonder why the government can't do more
to protect them Paul Adams BBC news
